body:
Would also be good if someone could test setting up environment on windows under the current installation instructions.

I feel this also has to do with the binder fix of @corvusrabus which required a two-step approach, and possibly with work done by @freddyaboulton - perhaps you something wise to say about the above?

@fkiraly Regarding prophet, I think we need to switch over to the `prophet` package as opposed to `fbprophet`. I think the problem is that `fbprophet` is quite old and they list `pystan>=2.14` as a requirement. This causes `pystan` 3.2.0 to be installed which is actually not compatible with prophet! Prophet only supports pystan 2. `prophet` has the correct pin of `pystan~=2.19.1.1`. 

I modified the setup.py to list prophet instead of prophet and then changed `fbprophet.py` to import `prophet` instead of `fbprophet` and I think everything is working ok after only doing `pip install -e .[all_extras]` (granted, I'm on osx).  

Can you give that a shot? I guess the alternative is to list `pystan` 2.19 as a requirement (which is basically what we do in our ci) but I think just using `prophet` is cleaner.

Not sure what happened with `brotlipy`. I agree we should also list `esig` in `all_extras`. You can't even run the unit tests without it.

>I modified the setup.py

Where exactly? Don't see a new PR.
@fkiraly This is what I was talking about: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/1375
After installing C++ Build Tools, restart is also required, it would be good to write this in documentation[Windows]

> ```
> conda create --name sktime python=3.8
> conda activate sktime
> conda install brotlipy
> pip install -e .[all-extras]
> pip install pytest
> pip install esig
> conda install -c conda-forge fbprophet
> pip install numpy==1.19.5 --force-reinstall
> ```


The above instructions worked for me. I had to run additional commands to install fbprophet as suggested by @aiwalter 
Here they are for reference:
option 1
```
conda install libpython m2w64-toolchain -c msys2
pip install pystan --no-cache
pip install fbprophet
```
option 2 (this worked for me)
```
conda install -c anaconda ephem
conda install -c conda-forge pystan
conda install -c conda-forge fbprophet
```
@fkiraly @aiwalter should I create a PR to include the above instructions in the installations doc?

> @fkiraly @aiwalter should I create a PR to include the above instructions in the installations doc?

That would be excellent!

Also, kindly ensure these work with a new environment, to ascertain that this can be repeated.

issue.title: Issues faced while installing development version on windows machine.

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
I am working on windows 10 OS, Anaconda 4.5.4. After following the instructions for the development version given in https://www.sktime.org/en/latest/installation.html, Here is my feedback:
Requirements.txt says fbprophet is needed but https://www.sktime.org/en/latest/installation.html#facebook-prophet says install prophet. There's a clash here as both require different versions of cmdstanpy.
Also, 2.19 version of pystan is not compilable in my environment for some reason, hence installed 2.18 version, which worked fine.
I installed build tools 2019, but during installation of pystan "conda install libpython m2w64-toolchain -c msys2" was run, and maybe due to this during compiling sktime, MinGW is being used as opposed to msvc, this caused compilation error due to openmp. Hence pip editable install did not work for me.
As a solution, I had to "python setup.py build --compiler=msvc install", which finally worked.
